awd_titl_txt: ATD: Algorithm, Analysis, and Prediction for Nonlinear and Non-Stationary Signals via Data-Driven Iterative Filtering Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
Have you ever wondered how to separate two conversations recorded at the same time in one room or how to identify irregular patterns in a electrocardiogram reading? In signal processing, those tasks are called de-mixing, which is very challenging, especially when the signals are mixed in a time-varying manner (non-stationary), or when they are not simply added together (nonlinear). The standard methods, such as the algorithms based on classical Fourier analysis or wavelets, can work effectively for linear and stationary signals, but are not as satisfactory for nonlinear or non-stationary signals. Developing algorithms that can handle such signals becomes a timely task that inspires a wave of research in recent years. A new method, named adaptive local iterative filtering (ALIF) is proposed in this project. ALIF can decompose a non-stationary and nonlinear signal into finitely many components, each of which is called an intrinsic mode function (IMF) that reflects the local property at a certain frequency. ALIF is a nonlinear process that can be adaptive according to the input signals, and can separate different local features (frequencies) automatically.  ALIF will also be used together with a machine learning method called factorization machine (FM) to develop a novel signal prediction strategy. It is expected that the ALIF and its prediction algorithms can be used in various applications such as chemical and biological threat detections, ionospheric radio power scintillation in geophysics, data classification and prediction in social media, and financial data analysis.

Nonlinear and non-stationary signals are ubiquitous in real world applications, and they often cannot be handled effectively by the standard algorithms based on Fourier/wavelet transforms, due to the non-linearity and/or their time-varying nature. To capture features, especially the hidden ones, in these signals, it is necessary for the analysis methods to be local, adaptive and stable. The focus of this project has two parts: 1) designing data adaptive algorithms that involve techniques such as iterative filtering for the time frequency analysis; and 2) developing prediction strategies using adaptive iterative filtering techniques in conjunction with the neural networks on nonlinear and non-stationary signals. In the first part, an adaptive local iterative filtering (ALIF) is designed to decompose nonlinear and non-stationary signals, without knowing its instantaneous frequency information in advance. Accompanied with ALIF is a new way, based on dynamical system concepts, to calculate the instantaneous frequencies for decomposed signals. The second part of the project is on a feature prediction strategy, using ALIF together with the factorization machine from neural networks, to learn and predict useful features from noisy signals. In both parts, the mathematical properties, such as convergence and stability of the proposed algorithms, are at the center of studies along with various applications including chemical and biological threat detection, ionospheric radio power scintillation in geophysics, and financial data analysis. The research topic contains a wide range of problems that can be used as projects suitable for undergraduate and graduate education, and postdoctoral scholar training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nonlinear and non-stationary signals are ubiquitous in real world applications. Examples can be found in cardiology signal analysis for medical diagnosis, defect inspection in materials, harmful chemical or biological threat detections, and seismic recordings, just to name a few.  The standard methods, such as those based on Fourier analysis or wavelets, can work remarkably well for linear and stationary signals, but not as satisfactory when the signals are collected from nonlinear or non-stationary processes, like gearbox in mechanics and ionospheric radio power scintillation in geophysics. The goal of this project is designing effective algorithms that can extract useful features, especially the hidden ones, from nonlinear and non-stationary signals, and conducting analysis that builds the mathematical foundation for the developed methods.

 

Intellectual merits:  This grant supported the PI and his research group to work on multiple directions in this field. The following are three selected results.

 

Recovering missing data or predicting the future trend in time series are considered two vital data mining tasks faced in various practical problems. They are often subjected to significant challenges, especially when the signals are nonlinear, non-stationary, and noisy. To accomplish the goals, the PI and his collaborators developed two algorithms, namely EMD2FNN and IF2FNN, which integrate modern signal decomposition methods such as empirical mode decomposition (EMD) and iterative filtering (IF) with machine learning strategies like factorization-machine neural network (FNN). They are end-to-end algorithms designed for data restoration and predictions, and they have been used in various applications including land-ocean temperature index analysis, stock market predictions, and the detection of epileptic seizures from Electroencephalography (EEG) signals. Along this line of research, the PI and his former postdoc conducted in-depth mathematical analysis proving the convergence of IF algorithms. Based on the analysis, they developed a fast algorithm called FIF that accelerates the speed of IF with two order of magnitude improvement.

 

Optimal transport has become an important mathematical theory in study data science in the past decade. It is particularly useful when dealing with problems involving data matching, like online dating, labor market, and college applications. In those problems, the cost, a crucial function in the optimal transport formulation that determines how to match pairs, is often unknown. Finding the cost is called inverse optimal transport. Working with his collaborators, the PI proposed a unified data driven framework, the first of this kind, that can learn the nonlinear adaptive interaction cost function from noisy and incomplete empirical sample observations and predict new pairs in various contexts, such as matching taxi and passenger from taxi driving data set in New York city.

 

Solving high-dimensional partial differential equations (PDE) is a long-standing challenge in scientific computing. The PI and collaborators proposed a new strategy, called weak adversarial network (WAN), that leverages the weak solution formulation and adversarial neural network to solve high-dimensional PDEs. WAN is suitable for PDEs defined on irregular domains and their solutions containing various discontinuities, for which the classical algorithms cannot be applicable.

 

The PI also worked on several other projects. The research activities were collaborative in nature, including joint investigations with experts in engineering and computer science.

 

Broader Impacts: During the span of this grant, the PI supervised 4 Ph.D. students who defended their thesis successfully. He mentored one post-doctoral scholar. Currently, he is advising 3 Ph.D. students.

 

The PI co-organized multiple conferences and workshops. He initiated the Georgia Tech mathematics and application portal (GT-MAP), which is platform for mathematician, scientist and engineers to exchange ideas and collaborations. He gave more than several dozens of presentations on his research results in national and international workshops and conferences, seminars and colloquia. He have been serving on multiple editorial boards for journals in the fields.
